column1: Ankle arthroscopy is surgery that uses a tiny camera and surgical tools to examine or repair the tissues inside or around your ankle.
During the procedure, the surgeon does the following: - Inserts the arthroscope into your ankle through a small incision.
A tear in a muscle, tendon, or cartilage is fixed.
At the end of the surgery, the incisions will be closed with stitches and covered with a dressing (bandage).
Arthroscopy may be recommended for these ankle problems: - Ankle pain: Arthroscopy allows the surgeon to explore what is causing your ankle pain.
- Arthritis: Arthroscopy can be used to help reduce pain and improve movement.

Risks of anesthesia and surgery in general are: - Allergic reactions to medicines - Breathing problems - Bleeding, blood clot, or infection Risks of ankle arthroscopy are: - Failure of surgery to relieve symptoms - Failure of repair to heal - Weakness of the ankle - Injury to tendon, blood vessel, or nerve
